awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Precision Docking for Automated Charging of Unmanned Platforms and Electric Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable automated and autonomous charging of a wide array of electric vehicles (e.g., electrified robots, cars and trucks, and drones) in adverse weather conditions.  Examples include autonomous systems used in farming and logistics, electric vehicles in ports, and electric trucks. Despite tremendous progress and the proliferation of electric vehicles, an adequate, cost-effective, autonomous, and available charging infrastructure is currently lacking. This gap between need and availability is far worse in high power applications such as trucking. The proposed technology increases the deployment of autonomous mobile robots and drones in industries like agriculture and logistics which are currently suffering from labor issues.  The technology may increase the deployment rate of commercial electric vehicle fleets that can contribute to reducing greenhouse gasses.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to solve a key problem in the automation of the charging process for electric vehicles, namely precision localization and docking in adverse weather conditions. The conventional methods of localization for docking (e.g., infrared or vision-based) have limitations such as insufficient precision and limited performance in less-than-optimal environmental conditions. This team presents a high precision automated docking solution in the presence of clutter and removes objects that are potentially harming the Line of Sight (LOS). The goals of the proposed research and development are: 1) establishing that time averaged, multi-path signal characteristics in multiple spectral bands can identify locations within a known map or during a close proximity approach of the electric vehicle to the charger; 2) developing models suitable for Monte-Carlo modeling and simulation of an indoor environment or region in proximity of a charger benchmarked by some measurements and using such simulations for verification success; and 3) developing a high precision transponder based on wideband signaling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
There is a rapid expansion of the use of electrified systems from robots to drones, Electric Vehicles (EVs), industrial machines, and so on with one underlying characteristic feature, the need for frequent charging. Autonomous or automated charging of such systems without the human operator has a range of applications from agriculture to mining and deep space operations to charging of industrial machines in ports where safety concerns dominate, in addition to providing significant savings in CAPEX and OPEX. Such a solution requires a precision docking mechanism that if functional in an all-weather adverse environment, is a key enabler of many applications and essential for future broadening and growth in the use of autonomous electrified machines. In this project, we have developed several technologies addressing the autonomous charging problem. For outdoor and indoor localization, Ray-Tracing simulation methodologies have been developed to find Channel Impulse Responses (CIRs) below 10GHz and at millimeter wave (mmWave) frequency bands. Subsequently, a deep Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) was trained from indoor measurement data to perform localization from the CIRs with reasonable accuracy. For close range precision docking, a RADAR-transponder based system has been developed with potential for millimeter level range measurement accuracy. We designed, developed, implemented and tested a system leveraging Components Off The Shelf (COTS) that would allow the mmWave RADAR unit to precisely measure range to a transponder. The system has been designed to distinguish multiple transponders at the same time generating three or more range information from transponders to RADAR while eliminating the effect of background clutter, thus allowing triangulation for precise relative localization of the RADAR system from a target on which the transponders are strategically placed. Application of the technology goes far beyond autonomous charging. More broadly, the developed technology finds broad application in Augmented Reality (AR).


Last Modified: 07/22/2024
Modified by: Fred Daneshgaran
